raw_text:
Choose hope over fear - Kennedy
 
 Voters will have a clear choice between the politics of fear and the politics of hope in the next general election, said Charles Kennedy.
 
 In his New Year message the Liberal Democrat leader said Labour and the Conservatives were united in relying on fear and "populist scares". He said his party was the one of hope and was ready for a 2005 poll. On the Asian tsunami he said it had been "very heartening" to learn of the generosity being shown by Britons. Mr Kennedy said his thoughts were with all those caught up in the disaster, which had dominated the Christmas and New Year period. At home he said many people were turning to the Liberal Democrats as they became disheartened with the politics of the other two main parties.
 
 The general election would be a three-party struggle, as the Conservative party "fades away" as a national force and the Liberal Democrats challenge Labour in its heartlands, he said. "A clear division is emerging in British politics - the politics of fear versus the politics of hope. "Labour is counting on the politics of fear, ratcheting up talk of threats, crime and insecurity. While the Conservatives are re-working their populist scares about asylum and the European 'menace'," he said. He said the government was using this climate of fear to try to strip away civil liberties.
 
 It was already using detention without trial at Belmarsh Prison, ignoring a recent Law Lords judgement that this contravenes basic human rights, he said. He also criticised attempts to bring in trial without jury, plans to lower the burden of proof in some criminal trials, curbing of rights to protest, increased stop and search powers and ID card plans. He said while everyone had the right to be secure they also had the right to be protected against unfair discrimination. "But at the same time, an overmighty state is a dangerous one," he said. His party "instinctively" understood the "new liberal Britain" which is no longer a nation with one family structure, and one colour, he said. "We are less deferential; more inclined to think for ourselves; more open about sexuality and equality. "Our national institutions are changing too. We are no longer a nation of one church; we are a nation of many faiths. In our attitudes and the way we live our lives, this is in many ways a liberal Britain."
llama3.2:1b: Charles Kennedy says voters should choose between politics of fear or hope in the next general election. He accuses Labour and Conservatives of relying on "populist scares" and says Liberal Democrats are the only party offering hope. He notes that his party was strong enough to win a 2005 poll, despite being less popular than others at home.
llama3.2:3b: Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy said voters will have a choice between the politics of fear and hope in the next general election. He claimed Labour and Conservatives rely on fear-based tactics and accused them of stripping away civil liberties. The Liberal Democrats, he said, are the party of hope, offering a more open and inclusive Britain where people can think for themselves and live their lives without unfair discrimination.
gemma2:2b: Charles Kennedy argues that the 2005 general election will be a choice between "politics of fear" used by Labour and Conservatives, and his party's "politics of hope." He criticizes both parties for using fear-mongering tactics on issues like crime, asylum, and European integration. He argues that while maintaining safety is important, the government should not infringe on civil liberties through measures like detention without trial, trial without jury, lower burden of proof in criminal trials, curtailing protest rights, increased stop and search powers, or ID cards. Kennedy stresses that the Liberal Democrats embrace a "new liberal Britain" characterized by diversity and equality, a departure from past national traditions.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key ideas:
- Kennedy argues for a clear choice between fear and hope in the general election.
- Liberal Democrats are united in relying on fear as Labour and Conservatives do.
- The General Election will be three-party struggle with Conservative party fading.
- "Politics of fear" is used to justify the government's actions, including detention without trial at Belmarsh Prison.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy calls on voters to choose between the politics of fear and hope in the upcoming general election, contrasting it with Labour's reliance on fear tactics and the Conservatives' populist scaremongering. The general election will be fought by three parties: Labour, the Conservatives, and the Liberal Democrats. The Liberal Democrats are positioning themselves as a force for hope against the "politics of fear."
qwen2.5:3b: Voters will face a choice between Labour's fear-mongering politics and the Liberal Democrats' hope-driven approach in next year's general election, according to Charles Kennedy. He criticizes Labour’s emphasis on threats, crime, and insecurity as well as the Conservatives' populist scares about asylum and Europe. Kennedy highlights how civil liberties are being stripped under current government policies like detention without trial and lowering jury trials. He also notes that Liberal Democrats understand a new liberal Britain with diverse family structures, openness to sexuality equality, and multiple faiths.
opencoder:1.5b: Voters will have a clear choice between the politics of fear and the politics of hope in the next general election. In his New Year message, the Liberal Democrat leader said Labour and the Conservatives were united in relying on fear and "populist scares". Mr Kennedy said his thoughts were with all those caught up in the disaster. At home he said many people were turning to the Liberal Democrats as they became disheartened with the politics of the other two main parties. The general election would be a three-party struggle, as the Conservative party "fades away" as a national force and the Liberal Democrats challenge Labour in its heartlands.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary above captures the main ideas and key points from the original text:

* The author's overall message is that hope over fear is the dominant theme of the next general election campaign.
* They emphasize the Liberal Democrats' role as the party of hope, highlighting their ability to unite voters across different political parties.
* The author contrasts the politics of fear with the politics of hope, arguing that the latter is more appealing and unifying for voters.
* They criticize Labour's use of populist scares and its attempts to strip away civil liberties, while also praising the Conservative Party's efforts to address these issues.
* The author highlights the Liberal Democrats' commitment to human rights and their criticism of the government's handling of these issues.
* They emphasize the importance of individual freedoms and the need for a more open and tolerant society in contrast to the politics of fear.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:

The first paragraph talks about Charles Kennedy's message in his New Year address regarding the next election. He mentions Labour and Conservatives relying on fear, while Labour sees itself as hopeful with a potential 2005 poll.

Next, he discusses the Asian tsunami. He says Britons were generous, but now they're "very heartening" to learn of the disaster's impact. His thoughts are with those affected during Christmas and New Year.

Then, at home, many people are turning to the Liberal Democrats because their political environment is dominated by the other two parties, leading to disheartlement.

The general election will be a three-party struggle as Conservatives fade out, and Labour challenges them in their heartlands. He talks about Labour counting on fear for threats, crime, and insecurity, while Conservatives reworking their policies around asylum and the European 'menace'.

He criticizes efforts to bring trial without jury, lower proof burden in criminal trials, restrict rights to protest, increase search powers, and ID cards. He also points out that an overpowered state is dangerous.

Kennedy mentions that his party instinctively understands a new liberal Britain with varied family structures. He acknowledges when they've become less like a single nation but more diverse. His institutions are evolving too, moving from one church to many faiths in how people live their lives and live their lives freely.

Finally, he calls for respect among those affected by the disaster, acknowledging that while there's hope, the state is overpowering.

The text discusses Charles Kennedy's New Year message, highlighting a three-party election scenario where Labour is counted on for fear, while Conservatives focus on hope. It also mentions the impact of an Asian tsunami, with Britons being heartening about its magnitude, and home politicians expressing frustration with the political dynamics between Labour, Conservatives, and others. The text notes Kennedy's criticism of legal trials, increased surveillance, ID cards, and the societal changes in British politics influenced by a new liberal Britain.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Liberal Democrats' leader Charles Kennedy summarized the state of British politics by citing a three-party struggle between the Conservative party, which is "fading away," and his own party, the Liberal Democrats. He emphasized that there is a clear divide in British politics between fear and hope, with Labour as a national force fading away while the Conservatives continue to use their populist scares about asylum and the European "menace" to try to strip away civil liberties. Kennedy also criticized attempts to bring in trial without trial at Belmarsh Prison, plans to lower the burden of proof in some criminal trials, curbing of rights to protest, increased stop and search powers, and ID card plans that could lead to unfair discrimination. Kennedy underscored his own party's instinctual understanding of "new liberal Britain" with its commitment to individual liberty and social equality, while still acknowledging the need for change in national institutions.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Charles Kennedy, a prominent Liberal Democrat leader, expressed his hope for a future election where voters will have a clear choice between politics based on fear and politics of hope. The general election would be a three-party struggle, with the Conservatives fading away as a national force, while the Liberal Democrats aim to challenge Labour in their heartland by framing the election as a battle between fear and hope.
phi:2.7b:
The text summary could be something like:

He says his party offers a positive alternative and is ready for a tough challenge from them. orca-mini:3b: Charles Kennedy said in his New Year message that the next general election would be a three-way struggle between Labour, the Liberal Democrats and the Conservatives, with the politics of fear being used by Labour and the Conservatives while the Liberal Democrats were challenging them in their heartlands. He also criticised the government's use of detention without trial at Belmarsh Prison, plans to lower the burden of proof in some criminal trials, curbing of rights to protest, increased stop and search powers and ID card plans.
hermes3:3b:
Choose hope over fear - Kennedy
Charles Kennedy says voters will face choice between politics of fear (Labour/Conservatives) and politics of hope (Lib Dems). Liberal Democrats are party of hope ready for 2005 election.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Charles Kennedy, leader of the Liberal Democrats, emphasized hope over fear during his New Year message, contrasting the politics of fear practiced by Labour and Conservatives with their own party's message of hope. He highlighted the impact of fear on both main parties, stating that many people were turning to the Liberal Democrats due to disillusionment. Kennedy predicted a three-party struggle in the general election, with the Conservative party fading away and the Liberal Democrats challenging Labour in its heartlands. He criticized the government for using fear to strip away civil liberties, such as detention without trial, lowering the burden of proof in some trials, and limiting rights to protest. Despite the changing nature of British society, Kennedy expressed optimism for his party's understanding of "new liberal Britain."

granite3.1-dense:2b: Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrat leader, emphasized a choice between politics of fear and hope in the upcoming general election. He criticized Labour's reliance on fear-based rhetoric, such as threats of crime and insecurity, and the Conservatives' populist scares about asylum and European influence. Kennedy highlighted the government's erosion of civil liberties, including detention without trial at Belmarsh Prison, attempts to institute trial without jury, and plans for ID cards. In contrast, he portrayed his party as a beacon of hope, representing a more open, inclusive society with diverse faiths and evolving attitudes on sexuality and equality.
